qas.question: Where was the location of the Crucifixion detailed?
What was one reason Calvary was chosen?
What is rumored to be found in Calvary?
What is a reason the place was called Calvary?

answers.text: the name was derived from the physical contour

qas.question: What language did most Romans know how to speak?
Where did the Romans usually speak Aramaic?
What did Romans do with Aramaic after they began speaking Latin?
On top of what formation was the Roman empire located?
What type of punishment did most people suffer who were buried in a nearby cemetery?

context: <a0_0>Calvary<a0_0/> as an English name for the place is derived from the Latin word for skull (calvaria), which is used in the Vulgate translation of "place of a skull", the explanation given in <a1_0>all four Gospels<a1_0/> of the <b5_0>Aramaic<b5_0/> word Gûlgaltâ which was the name of the place where Jesus was crucified. The text does not indicate why it was so designated, but several theories have been put forward. One is that as <a2_0>a place of <b6_0>public<b6_0/> <b9_0>execution<b9_0/><a2_0/>, Calvary may have been strewn with the <a3_0>skulls of <b7_0>abandoned<b7_0/> victims<a3_0/> (which would be contrary to Jewish burial traditions, but not Roman). Another is that Calvary is named after a nearby cemetery (which is consistent with both of the proposed modern sites). A third is that <a4_0>the name was derived from the physical contour<a4_0/>, which would be more consistent with the singular use of the word, i.e., the place of "a skull". While often referred to as "Mount Calvary", it was more likely <b8_0>a small hill<b8_0/> or rocky knoll.
